Description: A set of twenty-seven metalcuts from a Sarum 'Horae' probably printed in Paris (by F. Regnault?), or possibly English copies of French originals: Christ carrying the cross (69); Nativity (59); Christ before Pilate (64); angel appearing to shepherds (60); Christ shown to the people (65); Adoration of the Magi (61); Road to calvary (66); Circumcision (62); Flight into Egypt (63); Deposition (67); Assumption (71); Entombment (68); Joah murdering Uriah (53); David repenting for his sins (54); David offering a lamb in sacrifice (55 and 56); David appointing Solomon as his successor in the presence of his mother Bathsheba (57); David handing his crown to Solomon (58); Adam and Eve expulsed from Eden (50); Adam and Eve after the Fall (51); God creating Adam (49); damned souls burning in hell (78); a vignette showing a man being born and another dying (76); a dying figure is given the last rites while an angel appears above his bed and a demon pulls his sheets (77); the persecution of Job (52); figures with a devil (73); the Virgin and Child surrounded by musician angels (72); parable of Lazarus and the rich man (74); a procession carrying a monstrance (75); St John writing his evangile (70). 1525, late impressions (?) Metalcut with letterpress
Curator's comments: The prints are kept in an enveloppe bearing the following annotation: "Cuts from a Sarum 'Horae' probably printed in Paris (by F. Regnault?) dated 1525, but probably late impressions". A handwritten note accompanies the prints: "Cuts from a Sarum 'Horae' printed in Paris, or possibly English copies of French originals. The edition appears not to be in the British Museum. The same compositions, in reverse, with the same verses, occur in the edition printed by Thielman Kerver, Paris, 1528. The cuts are superior to these. According to that edition, the order of the subjects is as follow: 69, 59, 64,60, 65, 61, 66, 62, 63, 67, 71, 68, 53, 54, 55, 57, 58, 50, 51, 49, 78, 76, 77, 52, 73. The remaining Nos 72, 56, 74, 75, 70 are subjects which do not occur in the edition of 1528".
